Award.AwardTitle: PBS NewsHour Coverage of Non-Medical, Non-Clinical Care Research Addressing The Ebola Challenge

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID proposal was submitted in response to the NSF Dear Colleague letter soliciting proposals related to research addressing the Ebola challenge. The PBS NewsHour will produce 8 Television reports and Web coverage of scientists, engineers, mathematicians, and computer and technology experts as they apply their knowledge to tackling the Ebola virus. The programs will be distributed nationally through PBS, the NewsHour website, and multiple social media channels reaching a large national audience.

The public needs to be kept informed about the research into Ebola in a way that is understandable to a broad general audience. Current news reports focus primarily on the immediate crisis of the victims and medical personnel while less so on the science of Ebola. The NewsHour programs will instead help people learn about the non-medical, non-clinical care research that can help lead to solutions about Ebola; information that may also be applicable to similar diseases. The videos and web content will show and explain the scientific work being done by some of the leading scientists, engineers, computer experts and big data gatherers. These researchers' stories and work will be told in ways that will be engaging to a large and diverse audience, increasing their knowledge of the scientific, engineering, and mathematical/computer data/modeling work that is critical to solving the Ebola crisis.

The PBS NewsHour has significant reach through its nightly national broadcasts, its website, and its large social media following. Over 300 PBS stations broadcast the program each week night reaching 1.4 million people (11% African American and 51% female). The website has 3.8 million unique visitors and there are 575,000 Twitter followers. In addition over 1.5 million registered teachers use the PBS NewsHour educational materials. The videos and transcripts will be consolidated on the NewsHour website where they will exist permanently providing a resource for the public and researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PBS NewsHour produced eight tape reports plus accompanying Web elements to showcase the work of scientists, engineers, mathematicians and computer and technology experts as they applied their knowledge to tackling the Ebola virus.  We wanted to capture what was being done at universities and other labs, giving their research and accomplishments attention while presenting the information in an accessible form to a broad general audience. When we started the project, Americans were afraid that Ebola was going to strike close to home.  Fear was spreading and scenes of death were all that were featured on most of the media.   We wanted to show that scientists had some answers, that something indeed could be done.

The segments we produced on air and online accomplished what we set out to do. Two of the video reports focused on how to make the treatment of Ebola patients safer for front line providers. In Texas, we showed how much robots could do –from transport to handling waste to disinfecting hospital rooms – and what more was needed before robots were ready for the developing world.  In Maryland, we joined 60 participants including a wedding dress designer at a hackathon, as they brainstormed a safer, more comfortable hazmat suit for health workers. Their resulting design was one of 15 chosen by USAID to be funded.

Two of our segments updated the struggle to find vaccines. In Sierra Leone and Liberia, we explained the different vaccines being tested for efficacy and safety, and the challenges faced by providers and volunteer recipients alike. Humans are not the only ones suffering from Ebola:  tens of thousands of apes and chimpanzees also have died. We examined the vaccine being tested on the primates, and the roadblocks those scientists face.

Researchers are also anxious to find the carrier in nature of the Ebola virus. We followed members of the Viral Hemorrhagic Fever Consortium into the field in Sierra Leone as they trapped rats and – at great personal risk – necropsied them. Some species of bats were suspected of first bringing Ebola to humans but that had been hard to prove.  In determining the genetic link, the lab also has been critical: back in the U.S., we showcased the work of computational genomicist Pardis Sabeti who led the study that made the genetic link between the index case and the thousands that followed, all from human-to-human contact.    

Of course, all the efforts being expended on Ebola are for the purpose of saving lives. Three of our reports focused specifically on ways to ensure fewer cases and more survivors. Many more patients could be saved if there were a more definitive and faster test for the disease. The need was brought home in our piece from Sierra Leone, where two young boys, kept apart from their neighbors, had their temperatures taken daily to see if they had caught the disease from their parents. It was a heart wrenching and ineffective way to make that decision. The alternative was a pricey, cumbersome and not easily available genetic test. The report compared newer tests that were being created in the U.S. and explained their design, strengths and weaknesses.

We also reported on treatment for those with the disease, focusing on the drug ZMapp that had proven effective in treating some Ebola patients.  We explained how ZMapp was grown on tobacco plants and what such biopharmaceuticals could mean for the prevention and treatment of other illnesses.

Big data turned out to have a big role to play in stopping the epidemic.
